moves.2... d5 3. Nxe5 f6 4. Ng4 Nh6 5. Be2: I kind of like NxNh6 instead.
moves.5... Nxg4 6. Bxg4 Bxg4 7. Qxg4 Qe7: Here white should play Qc8+, followed by QxPb7.  Black would most likely intercede with Qd8, then Nd7 to defend Ra1.  White picks up Pb7 and Pd5.
moves.8. d3 Nd7 9. Nc3 g6 10. Nxd5 Qd6 11. Bf4: Ne5 will prevent white forking the king and rook.
That pawn doesn't really protect the bishop from capture by Pb4.
moves.27... Qxa3: Though black now has two passed pawns, they might not be salvageable.
moves.28. Qg4+ Ke5 29. Qxh4 Rf3: Ra1 gives white Pa7, since Nd5 defends against Qe7.
moves.30. Ne3: Black must defend against Nc4+, forking the black queen.  Pb5 does that, or moving the king or queen.
moves.31. Qg3 Qf8 32. f3 Qc5: Oops.  White picks up both queen and rook.
